title: Wound Cleansing: The Foundation of Proper Wound Care
description: Complete guide to wound cleansing techniques, products, and protocols that create clean, healthy wound beds and prevent infection.

sections.heading: Why Wound Cleansing Matters
sections.content:
Cleaning a chronic wound is crucial for its proper healing. Think of wound cleansing as giving your wound a spa session—it cleanses the tissues, removes debris, revitalizes tissues, and improves circulation to help prevent infection and optimize healing.

Between visits to your wound care provider, it is equally important to continue cleaning the wound. This means gently washing and refreshing the wound bed according to your wound care provider's instructions with every dressing change. Daily wound cleansing keeps the wound environment optimal for healing and allows you to monitor for any concerning changes.

callout.title: The Golden Rule
callout.content: Clean wounds heal faster. A properly cleansed wound bed has less bacterial contamination, better blood flow, and creates the ideal environment for new tissue growth. Conversely, wounds with accumulated debris, drainage, and bacteria face an uphill battle for healing.

sections.heading: Understanding Wound Cleansers
sections.content:
Wound cleansers may contain soaps, specific enzymes, and sometimes emulsifiers—all of which are designed to help break down and remove dirt, debris, and bacteria from the wound bed. The right cleanser depends on your wound type, infection status, and the amount of debris present.

Your wound care doctor will recommend the most appropriate cleanser for your specific wound. This isn't a one-size-fits-all decision—different wounds require different approaches.

sections.heading: Types of Wound Cleansers
sections.content: Here are the most common cleansing solutions and when they're used:

subsections.content:
**Best for:** All types of wounds; mild to moderate severity

**What it is:** Sterile salt water solution (0.9% sodium chloride) that matches the body's natural fluid composition

**Advantages:**
• Gentle and non-toxic to healing tissue
• Does not sting or cause pain
• Isotonic—won't damage cells
• Inexpensive and widely available
• Safe for all wound types
• Can be used multiple times daily

**Disadvantages:**
• Limited antimicrobial properties
• May not remove heavy debris effectively

**How to use:** Gently irrigate wound with saline, allowing it to flow over wound surface. Pat dry with sterile gauze.

**Gold standard** for routine wound cleansing—safe, effective, and gentle.

**Best for:** Minor wounds only; avoid in deep or chronic wounds

**What it is:** Weak acid (H₂O₂) that fizzes when it contacts tissue, helping to lift debris

**Advantages:**
• Readily available
• Inexpensive
• Bubbling action lifts debris
• Familiar to most people

**Disadvantages:**
• Damages healing tissue and new cells
• Can delay wound healing
• Toxic to fibroblasts (cells that build new tissue)
• Effectiveness decreases rapidly after opening bottle

**Important:** Most wound care professionals NO LONGER recommend hydrogen peroxide for chronic wounds. While it may seem to 'clean' the wound, it actually damages the delicate healing tissue. Reserve for initial cleaning of acute injuries only.

**How to use (if recommended):** Dilute 1:1 with water, use briefly only for initial cleaning, then switch to saline.

**Best for:** Infected wounds; not for use in deep wounds

**What it is:** Povidone-iodine or cadexomer iodine solutions with antimicrobial properties

**Advantages:**
• Broad-spectrum antimicrobial (kills bacteria, fungi, viruses)
• Effective for infected wounds
• Reduces biofilm formation

**Disadvantages:**
• Can be toxic to healing cells if used long-term
• May cause sensitivity/allergy
• Contraindicated for people with thyroid conditions
• Stains skin and clothing
• Should not be used continuously

**How to use:** Applied by healthcare provider for short-term use during active infection. Typically transitioned to gentler cleanser once infection is controlled.

**Best for:** Minor wounds; helps prevent infection

**What it is:** Topical antibiotic preparations like bacitracin, neomycin, or triple antibiotic ointment

**Advantages:**
• Prevents infection in minor wounds
• Creates moist healing environment
• Over-the-counter availability
• Easy to apply

**Disadvantages:**
• Not effective for established infections
• Can cause allergic reactions (especially neomycin)
• Not appropriate for deep or large chronic wounds
• Overuse can lead to antibiotic resistance

**How to use:** Thin layer applied after cleansing, covered with sterile dressing. Used primarily for minor acute wounds, not typically for chronic wounds.

**Best for:** All types of wounds; antimicrobial properties

**What it is:** Weak acid naturally produced by white blood cells, now available as a wound cleanser

**Advantages:**
• Powerful antimicrobial without tissue toxicity
• Gentle on healing tissue
• No sting or pain
• Safe for all wound types
• Reduces biofilm
• Can be used long-term
• Non-toxic and non-irritating

**Disadvantages:**
• More expensive than saline
• Shorter shelf life once opened
• Less widely available

**How to use:** Spray or irrigate wound generously, allow to sit briefly, then pat dry.

**Emerging favorite** among wound care specialists for its combination of antimicrobial power and gentleness.

**Best for:** Various wound types depending on formulation

**What it is:** Purpose-designed products containing surfactants, enzymes, or other agents

**Advantages:**
• Specifically formulated for wound care
• Often contain multiple beneficial ingredients
• Non-toxic to healing tissue
• Effective debris removal
• Easy to use (spray bottles)

**Disadvantages:**
• More expensive than saline
• Many different products—need guidance on selection

**Examples:** Wound Wash Saline, Prontosan, Vashe, Anasept

**How to use:** Follow product instructions; typically spray liberally and allow to flow over wound

sections.heading: Step-by-Step Wound Cleansing Procedure
sections.content: Follow these steps to ensure proper wound cleansing at home:

subsections.content:
• Disposable gloves (non-sterile is usually adequate)
• Clean towel
• Sterile gauze sponges or pads
• Saline solution, water, or prescribed cleanser
• Plastic trash bag
• Soft, clean towel for drying
• New wound dressing supplies

**1. Prepare**
• Wash your hands thoroughly with soap and water
• Gather all supplies so everything is within reach
• Create clean workspace

**2. Put on new gloves**
• Maintains cleanliness and prevents introducing bacteria
• Change gloves if they become contaminated during process

**3. Position and protect**
• Place a towel under the body part with the wound to catch any moisture or debris
• Position for easy access and good lighting

**4. Remove old dressing carefully**
• If dressing is stuck, moisten with saline to loosen
• Dispose in plastic trash bag
• Remove gloves, wash hands, put on new gloves

**5. Assess the wound**
• Look for signs of infection: redness, swelling, increased drainage, odor
• Note the tissue at the wound's bottom—should be light red or pink, may appear lumpy or glossy
• Observe any changes from previous dressing change

**6. Clean the wound**
• Wet gauze sponge or pad with saline solution or prescribed cleanser
• Ensure it's damp but not dripping
• Starting from the CENTER of the wound, gently clean in circular motions outward
• Extend cleaning at least one inch beyond the wound's edge
• **Critical: NEVER wipe from outer edges toward center**—this introduces bacteria INTO the wound

**7. Clean any drainage**
• Remove any liquid draining from the wound
• Use fresh gauze for each wipe
• Discard used gauze into plastic trash bag

**8. Rinse if needed**
• Use fresh gauze moistened with saline to rinse away any loosened debris
• Remove anything not eliminated during initial cleaning

**9. Pat dry**
• Gently pat (don't rub) the skin surrounding the wound with soft, clean towel
• Ensure area is thoroughly dry—moisture on surrounding skin can cause maceration
• The wound bed itself should remain slightly moist (don't dry it)

**10. Apply new dressing**
• Follow your provider's instructions for specific dressing type
• Secure appropriately

**11. Dispose of materials**
• Place all used materials including gloves in plastic trash bag
• Seal and dispose according to local guidelines
• Wash hands thoroughly

sections.heading: Wound Irrigation: Deep Cleaning Technique
sections.content:
For deeper wounds, wounds with tunneling, or wounds with significant debris, simple wiping isn't enough. Irrigation uses pressurized fluid to flush out the wound more thoroughly.

**When irrigation is needed:**
• Deep wounds or wounds with undermining/tunneling
• Heavy contamination or debris
• Thick, tenacious drainage
• Wounds with pockets or irregular surfaces

**Irrigation technique:**
• Use 30-60cc syringe (without needle) or commercial irrigation system
• Fill with saline or prescribed cleanser
• Hold tip 2-3 inches from wound
• Apply steady pressure to flush wound bed
• Angle spray to get into pockets and crevices
• Allow fluid to drain out (into basin or onto waterproof pad)
• Continue until drainage runs clear

**Safety note:** Your wound care provider will teach you proper irrigation technique if your wound requires it. Excessive pressure can damage tissue; insufficient pressure won't clean adequately.

callout.title: The Right Pressure
callout.content: Effective wound irrigation requires 8-12 psi (pounds per square inch) of pressure. This is roughly what you achieve with a 30-60cc syringe. Too little pressure won't remove debris; too much can damage tissue or force bacteria deeper. Commercial irrigation products are pre-set to optimal pressure.

sections.heading: What NOT to Use on Wounds
sections.content:
Avoid these common mistakes that can delay healing:

❌ **Hydrogen peroxide** (except for initial acute injury cleaning)
❌ **Rubbing alcohol**—extremely toxic to healing cells
❌ **Betadine for prolonged use**—can damage tissue over time
❌ **Soap directly in the wound**—use only on surrounding skin
❌ **Very hot or very cold water**—use lukewarm/room temperature
❌ **Cotton balls that shed fibers**—use gauze instead
❌ **Harsh scrubbing**—gentle technique only
❌ **Home remedies** (sugar, honey, etc.) unless specifically prescribed by healthcare provider

The principle: If it would hurt to put in your eye, don't put it in your wound. Healing tissue is delicate and sensitive.

sections.heading: Cleansing Frequency
sections.content:
How often you cleanse depends on several factors:

**Daily cleansing:**
• Wounds with heavy drainage
• Infected wounds
• Wounds requiring daily dressing changes

**Every 2-3 days:**
• Wounds with minimal drainage
• Wounds using moisture-retaining dressings that can stay in place longer
• As directed by your wound care provider

**With each dressing change:**
• Regardless of the dressing change schedule
• Even if the dressing "looks clean," refresh the wound bed

**The rule:** Never apply a new dressing without first cleansing the wound. Trapping old drainage and debris under a fresh dressing creates an ideal environment for bacterial growth.

sections.heading: Signs Your Cleansing Routine Is Working
sections.content:
You'll know your cleansing technique is effective when you see:

✓ Healthy pink or red tissue in the wound bed
✓ Decreasing wound size over time
✓ Minimal odor
✓ Clear or slightly bloody drainage (not cloudy, green, or foul-smelling)
✓ Skin around wound is healthy (not red, hot, or swollen)
✓ No increasing pain
✓ Granulation tissue appearing (bumpy, red healing tissue)

If you're NOT seeing these signs after 1-2 weeks of proper cleansing, consult your healthcare provider.

sections.heading: Special Considerations
sections.content:
Certain wound types require modified cleansing approaches:

**Infected wounds:**
• May require antimicrobial cleansers temporarily
• More frequent cleansing
• Careful monitoring

**Surgical wounds:**
• Follow surgeon's specific instructions
• May have restrictions on wetting certain incisions

**Diabetic ulcers:**
• Extra attention to removing callused tissue around edges
• Thorough inspection for any signs of infection

**Venous ulcers:**
• Gentle technique due to fragile surrounding skin
• Attention to controlling drainage

**Pressure injuries:**
• May require irrigation if deep or undermined
• Careful removal of slough and necrotic tissue

faqs.question: Can I use tap water to clean my wound?
faqs.answer: This depends on your wound type and local water quality. For most superficial wounds in areas with clean, potable tap water, it's acceptable for brief rinsing. However, sterile saline is always safer and preferred for chronic wounds, deep wounds, or wounds at high infection risk. Some areas have water that contains bacteria or chemicals that could harm wound healing. When in doubt, ask your healthcare provider. Bottled or boiled water is a middle-ground option.

faqs.question: My wound cleanser stings—is this normal?
faqs.answer: No. Proper wound cleansers should NOT sting or cause pain. Saline solution and hypochlorous acid are essentially painless. If your cleanser causes stinging, it may be too harsh (like hydrogen peroxide) or there may be infection present making the tissue more sensitive. Contact your wound care provider—you may need a gentler cleanser or evaluation for infection.

faqs.question: How do I clean a wound that's very painful to touch?
faqs.answer: First, take pain medication 30-60 minutes before the dressing change so it's at peak effectiveness. Use gentle irrigation rather than wiping—this is less traumatic. Ensure your cleanser is body temperature (warm it slightly if refrigerated). Work slowly and communicate with whoever is helping. Take breaks if needed. If pain remains severe despite these measures, contact your provider—you may need a different pain management approach or the pain could indicate infection.

faqs.question: Can I clean my wound in the shower?
faqs.answer: Sometimes, but ask your provider first. For some wounds, shower spray provides gentle irrigation and makes cleaning easier. However, other wounds (certain surgical wounds, wounds with grafts, very deep wounds) should not be exposed to shower water. If approved, use lukewarm water, let it flow over the wound without direct hard spray, and pat dry afterward. Never use bath water (sitting in dirty water)—shower only.

faqs.question: How do I know if my cleaning technique is making the wound worse?
faqs.answer: Warning signs include: increasing wound size, increasing pain during or after cleaning, increased redness around wound edges, new drainage or change in drainage color/odor, tissue that looks damaged or more yellow/black rather than pink/red. If you notice any of these, stop your current technique and contact your healthcare provider. You may be using too harsh a cleanser, too much pressure, or the wrong technique for your wound type.
